I live in Haiti, and the excuses never stop here. Many groan and moan about "how very complex" the situation is, while of course enjoying their six-figure salaries (excluding benefits!), their weekly jaunts to the beach, their chauffeured 4X4s, their endless workshops, their 5-hour coordination meetings, their pointless rounds of strategy-making, their "consultations" with "communities" that reveal the great insight that poor folks worry about and really want food, and that Haitians want their kids to be in school.

What would happen if people were charged with specific tasks, e.g., Haitian politicians and INGOs that play the blame-n-wink game, and actually held accountable for results?

Congratulations for covering this important story. A few years ago I was working on a study about leadership in tough development contexts. The focal question was, What leadership is required to get things done. We looked at rapid results in Gashaki, Rwanda, as well as in Sierra Leone, Burundi and Kenya. In all places we saw the power of this method, which reinforces many of the central ideas about how change happens. We found that the people felt empowered, able to identify and address their problems, with a better understanding of the need to push past obstacles rather than give up in the face of such, and a belief that they and their organizations could do better. One man told me that rapid results taught him not to wait for the donors. "I now know that I can be my own donor" he said. We found that leadership solutions happen in rapid results through groups of people mobilized around problems, which was also important. This is not a 'big man theory' of change, or a top down 'implementation by edict' or an imposed dependence...this is an approach that has he real potential to transform people and communities...and countries. Feel free to read the longer report. http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1551375.

Thirty years ago in the Midwest, training as a PA (physician assistant), being older, white and male, I learned from a resident, a younger, African-American woman and a medical fellow, a indeterminate age, East-Indian man.

Were patient's confused when we examined them as a team? Yes. I was always called "the doctor" even after correcting the patient. Something more was going on than just respect for a profession or title. I see something of the same continues today.

Patients will make mistakes that are easily corrected and easily avoided. A first encounter by the provider of care should always include an introduction to the patient:

My name is, I am a (physician, nurse, pharmacist, physical therapist, whatever) and a easily read name tag with initials MD, PA, RN, NP, PharmD, PT, OD, DDS, DPM, etc., etc.

Older now, I often need a physician (a teacher, care provider, adviser and counselor). They seem to be in short supply. A glance at my health care bills and one certainly and easily distinguishes who the "doctor" was. Better, they all avoid using that title when laying on hands.

Some medical students have doctorates in other fields (like science), but would never, ever refer to themselves as "Doctor" in front of the patient in a clinical setting. In the exam room, I think it's inappropriate for nurses to call themselves "doctor".

The Rapid Results approach  of providing structure is accompanied with respect for self determination.  Overseas Aid dollars are often more about what external experts can do, the rapid results focus is centered on what the community can do.   Many communities are confronted with complex and long standing issues, the bite size approach helps raise confidence, capabilities and motivation amongst those that have the vested interest in success i.e. the people that are affected most.  This is a powerful and effective tool, we need more sensible approaches like rapid results.
As a doctor - it strikes me that this approach might only work where the expertise required is not too sophisticated - yet RRI has had excellent results with their AIDS/SIDA effort.

I have some MBTs with the rockered bottoms. They're exceedingly heavy but they force me into better posture and they're very squishy for standing long hours in. As to the science of how many calories they burn and where, well, i doubt it. But i do like the way i perambulate in 'em. Some one should sue whoever put the concrete down that we in the first world have to walk and stand on. That was a bad idea.
Now, why every sneaker has to have 6 different day-glo colors on it in 2011 IS a question worth asking. Hey, Nike, though one couldn't tell from looking at a wall of your newest shoes, it's not 1986 anymore.

When I was very young, I persuaded my parents to buy me a pair of "P F Flyers" after seeing an ad on TV that promised that they would make me "run faster and jump higher."  Not much has changed since then except the price.

Because I had a knee injury, I stopped going for walks on hard surfaces  (such as cement) as the PT folks suggested.   Walking on a treadmill is boring, but at least the weather doesn't matter.   However, even with good walking shoes, my knee pain started flaring again.   I did a lot of online research and talked to my orthopedist.  He said that shoes that are good for the feet aren't necessarily good for the knees.  He recommended that I try the Vibrams.  Although I didn't conscioulsy make any changes my stride -- except that it's longer now that my knee doesn't hurt -- I find that they work quite well for me.

I have worked an a research RN along side graduates from foreign medical schools with medical degrees doing the same job. They were instructed NOT to sign documents with the term "doctor", or even "MD", because although they possessed the degree of MD, they lacked an American license or board certification.

Such a restriction was in place because it is assumed that the signee using "doctor" or "MD" is a licensed, board certified member of the hospital staff and not merely someone with a particular education.

This is the dumbest thing ever. I have a win predictor that works just as well -- common sense. Before the kick-off I disregard the odds and say well, either team could win. When one team gets more points I say, hey it looks like they'll win, but then when the other team scores more points I say wait a doggone minute -- they just might do it. I mean, when it looked like Victor Cruz fumbled and the Cards recovered I said oh, boy looks like Arizona is almost certain to win. But then when Nicks scored, I thought the Giants would win. The advantage is my common sense win probability indicator is a lot faster than your charts -- as soon as Nicks scored I said the Giants will probably win if they can just hold on.

And by golly I was right again. Whooeee!!!

Add Mallenco's 'performance,' which I did not see, with two featured matches on Saturday, Everton-Liverpool, and Inter-Napoli, which I did, and I am convinced that there is a full-on refereeing crisis. Now in both of those matches, the better side went on to win, but not without considerable help from the referees with dismal performances. At Goodison Park, Martin Atkinson dismissed Jack Rodwell for a tackle that wasn't even a foul, probably based upon Luis Suarez' spectacular embellishment. Liverpool probably would have won anyway, but they DID leave it late, and on a hot day, the decision reduced Everton's abilty to do more than draw.
In Milan, Signor Rocchi cautoned Joel Obi on a challenge similar to the 'foul' that got Rodwell dismissed, then had no choice but to send him off for a professsional fould later, but he took a foul clearly outside the box, and allowed the embellishment of a staggering, falling player influence him to call a penalty.

As for your Forrest Gump reference, the book is VERY different from the movie, but maybe the book's first line sentiments are more applicable to today's troubled referees: "Let me say this: Bein a idiot is no box of chocolates."

The NFL was integrated long before many other sporting outlets were in the US, particularly big time college sports n the American South. In 1966, an all white team from basketball power University of Kentucky (and its racist coach, Adolph Rupp) were beaten in the NCAA final by 5 black New Yorker starters of Texas Western (now UTEP-Texas @ El Paso), which Kentucky took, um, badly. Even later than that, football legend Bear Bryant intentionally schedlued a home game against integrated USC. USC's star running back Sam (Bam) Cunninham led a 28-0 rout that allowed Bryant to convince Alabamians that they had to integrate in order to compete. These events were well AFTER the Civil Rights Act which you trumpet so much.
The REASON why the Rooney Rule was developed was that, unlike on-field performance, team management is NOT a mertiocracy, and while every other element of the NFL, from the officials to the traning staff to the players were integrated (even quarterback, the last position bastion of white preference), the place where it just didn't happen was in coachng. This situation is still utterly, painfully true n England. The same old coaches keep getting recycled over and over again. Why has Steve Bruce gotten chance after chance to underachieve at Birmingham, at Wigan and now at Sunderland n the same period when his Man Utd teammate Paul Ince has gotten one, and only one, chance to climb the coaching ladder? Can you honestly say that Bruce knows that much more about how to run a team than Ince does? Pshaw. When Sparky Hughes walked away from Fulham (and HE got chance after chance at Blackburn, Man City and then Fulham), Fayed chose the ultimate recycling project, Martin Jol, because everybody saw how GREAT he was at Spurs, then at Hamburg, then at Ajax, right? And there are dozens of these recycled coaches around England. Me? I'd like to see a few black officials. They can't be worse than Martin Atkinson was at Goodison. But hn, you're wrong on the facts, plainly.
